summary.title: GUI Programming
summary.description: Modern Graphical User Interface (GUI) design and implementation methods are studied. The course uses Java and C++ as the base languages. Industry standard libraries, such as Swing, Microsoft Foundation Classes (MFC), Direct3D, and OpenGL are used throughout the semester for programming coursework.

book.title: Getting Started with Microsoft Visual C++ with an Introduction to MFC

course-outcomes.outcome: Declare, instantiate, and display Java Swing controls.
Create class methods that respond to Java Swing controls.
Combine Java controls to produce graphical user interfaces using various container classes.
Produce Java programs that run as either Applets or standalone applications.
Declare, instantiate, and display Windows MFC controls.
Create class methods that respond to Windows MFC controls.
Produce MFC applications using either frame windows or dialog boxes.
Send and receive data using dynamic dialog exchange (DDX).
Create a simple OpenGL or DirectX application utilizing 3D rendering.

course-content.topic: GUI "look and feel," good design practices, available compilers, a brief Java review, introduction to Swing, interfaces (implement) and superclasses (extend), JFrame, JOptionPane, and Java graphics using Paint().
Java containers, JLabel, JTextField, JpasswordField, and HTML used with Java.
Inner classes, event handlers, listeners, and Jbutton, JCheckBox, JRadioButton, JComboBox, and Jlist.
JSlider, mouse and keyboard handling, listeners vs. adapters.
Layout managers (FlowLayout, BorderLayout, GridLayout, BoxLayout, CardLayout, and GridBagLayout).
Java timers, exception handling and threads.
Web browser Applets and Applets that can be run as stand alone applications.
Introduction to Microsoft Foundation Classes (MFC), the Graphical Device Interface (GDI), and the MFC/Windows message queue.
MFC event handling, CButton, CEdit, CScrollbar, CRadioButton, CScrollBar, and CSlider.
MFC mouse and keyboard handling, CSpinButton.
MFC timers (WM_TIMER, multimedia timer, and performance timer).
Introduction to OpenGL, OpenGL in an MFC dialog box.
